answers.text: see how the app behaves and looks

quizzes.question: The Xcode simulator allows you to...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Run Simulator[/h1]

Xcode contains an app called [b]Simulator[/b], for use in building and running your app. Simulator provides an idea of how your app would look and behave if it were running on a device. 
Simulator has the capability of modeling a number of different types of hardware: iPad, iPhones with varying screen sizes, and so on. 
Choose your desired device from the  [b]Scheme [/b]pop-up menu; in this case, make sure that you select the [b]iPhone 6 Simulator[/b], not an iOS Device. [img id="993" width="100%"]
Click the [b]Run [/b]button, located in the top-left corner of the Xcode toolbar: [img id="994" width="100%"]Alternatively, choose Product > Run (or press Command-R).
When running an app for the first time, Xcode will ask whether you'd like to enable developer mode on your Mac. [img id="995" width="100%"]
[note]Xcode displays messages about the build process in the activity viewer, which is in the middle of the toolbar.[/note]

answers.text: display a launch screen with your app's name

quizzes.question: When the app launches on Simulator, it will...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Running your App[/h1]

After Xcode finishes building your project, Simulator starts automatically.
Before the app finishes launching, you'll briefly see a launch screen with your app's name, [i]MyApp[/i].  [img id="996" width="50%"]
Then, you should see something like this: [img id="997" width="50%"] 
Right now, the Single View Application template doesn't do much; it just displays a white screen.
[b]You have just created and launched your first iOS app![/b]
[note]You can quit Simulator by choosing Simulator > Quit Simulator or by pressing Command-Q.[/note]
